thread.title: Legislators cry foul as CDOT plans $150 million for new offices
thread.title_full: Legislators cry foul as CDOT plans $150 million for new offices - The Denver Post

author: Joey Bunch
title: Legislators cry foul as CDOT plans $150 million for new offices
text:
State legislators who have grappled to find money for roads and bridges are learning this week that the Colorado Department of Transportation could spend up to $150 million to replace its offices in Denver, Pueblo and Greeley.
That sends a mixed message about priorities, said Senate President Bill Cadman.
CDOT opposed an unsuccessful bill in the last session to authorize $3.5 billion in transportation bonds, to be paid back with half of CDOT's federal gas tax revenues, to fund 30 construction projects across the state. During hearings on the issue, CDOT representatives made no mention of plans to issue bonds for buildings, he said.
"I have a huge concern that they can say 'no' to roads, bridges and public safety, and 'yes' to bonding for themselves," Cadman said.
A 1990 law exempted CDOT and the state's colleges from needing legislative approval to build or improve facilities.
The bonds for buildings would be repaid from CDOT's existing budget for facilities.
Amy Ford, spokeswoman for the state highway department, said the bonds for roads and bridges is a separate issue. The agency opposed the transportation bonds because they came with no new revenue sources.
"It puts us on the hook to build new things without keeping any money in the bank to be able to maintain and operate those things," she said. "... We're sitting in buildings, many of which were built in the '30s, the '40s and the '50s and many of which were not designed for the capacity at which they are currently being used.
